passage:
(1) The invention of the wheel stands as one of humanity's most significant technological achievements. Archaeological evidence suggests that the wheel was first invented around 3500 BCE in Mesopotamia, modern-day Iraq. Initially, wheels were not used for transportation but rather for pottery making. The potter's wheel allowed artisans to create symmetrical pottery more efficiently than ever before. It wasn't until approximately 300 years later that wheels were adapted for use in chariots and carts, forever changing how humans would move goods and themselves across distances.

(2) The impact of the wheel on ancient civilizations was profound and far-reaching. With wheeled vehicles, people could transport heavier loads over longer distances with less effort. This innovation revolutionized trade, allowing merchants to expand their networks and exchange goods with distant communities. Agricultural societies benefited tremendously as farmers could move their harvests from fields to markets more efficiently. Military forces gained mobility and speed, changing the nature of warfare. The wheel essentially compressed time and space, connecting previously isolated communities and facilitating cultural exchange.

(3) Beyond transportation, the wheel concept influenced numerous other inventions throughout history. Gears, which are essentially interlocking wheels with teeth, became fundamental components in complex machinery. Water wheels harnessed the power of flowing rivers to grind grain and eventually generate electricity. Pulleys, another wheel-based technology, made it possible to lift heavy objects with minimal effort. These applications demonstrate how a single innovation can spark countless others, creating a cascade of technological advancement across different fields.

(4) In modern society, wheels remain essential to our daily lives, though we often take them for granted. From the tires on our vehicles to the caster wheels on office chairs, wheels facilitate movement in countless ways. Transportation systems worldwide—including cars, trains, and airplanes with their landing gear—rely fundamentally on the wheel. Manufacturing machinery, conveyor belts, and even many children's toys incorporate wheels in their design. Despite being thousands of years old, this ancient technology continues to underpin much of our modern infrastructure.

(5) The wheel serves as a powerful reminder of how a seemingly simple innovation can fundamentally transform human civilization. Its development required not only the concept of a circular object that could rotate around an axle but also the engineering knowledge to implement this idea effectively. The wheel's legacy teaches us that breakthrough technologies often emerge from solving practical problems and that such solutions can have implications far beyond their original purpose. As we continue to face global challenges today, the wheel's history inspires us to seek similarly transformative innovations that might reshape our collective future.

options.D: Military applications drive most technological innovations
